content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-284-07-B |Item_parent=Functional colopathy |Item_parent_short=Functional colopathy |Rank=B |Title=Know the differential diagnoses and the additional tests needed to rule them out |Description=NFS, CRP, TSH, Ac anti-transglutaminase +-parasitological examination of stools |Section=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=7}} The main differential diagnoses are inflammatory bowel disease, coeliac disease, microscopic colitis and iatrogenicity (drugs that alter transit or cause abdominal pain: metformin, colchicine, NSAIDs, etc.). It is useful to carry out a biological work-up in patients presenting with IBS. The aim is to rule out an organic pathology. A CBC will rule out anaemia, and a CRP will look for an inflammatory syndrome. In diarrhoea-predominant IBS, it is also advisable to measure TSH to rule out hyperthyroidism and IgA-type anti-transglutaminase antibodies to look for coeliac disease. A parasitological examination of the stools is recommended in the diarrhoeal subtype to rule out lambliasis. Radiological examinations have no place in typical forms of IBS.

question.title: What is the purpose of a biological work-up in patients presenting with Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)?

option_b.title: To rule out inflammatory bowel disease and other organic pathologies

option_c.title: To measure TSH levels to rule out hyperthyroidism
option_c.description: A partially correct but incorrect option

option_d.title: To perform a parasitological examination of the stools

correct_option.title: B
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the correct option
